Once hailed as a groundbreaking sequel to the original Overwatch, anticipation for Overwatch 2 reached a fever pitch among fans and gamers alike. The promise of updated graphics, new heroes, and innovative gameplay mechanics had players eagerly awaiting its release. However, when Overwatch 2 finally hit the shelves, the initial excitement quickly transformed into disappointment.

The game's visuals, touted as a major improvement, fell flat. Players were met with unpolished textures, choppy animations, and numerous graphical glitches that rendered the experience visually unappealing. Characters that were meant to look more detailed ended up resembling awkward caricatures, leaving fans longing for the clean and distinctive art style of the first game.

But the problems didn't stop at the visuals. Overwatch 2 suffered from severe balance issues, with new heroes introduced to the roster that were shockingly overpowered. Players found themselves facing an insurmountable disadvantage when pitted against these new characters, leading to frustration and a feeling of helplessness. The lack of proper testing and fine-tuning was evident, as matches often devolved into chaotic and one-sided battles.

Moreover, the gameplay changes that were promised only served to alienate long-time fans. The core mechanics that had made Overwatch enjoyable were altered in ways that fundamentally changed the feel of the game. Abilities that were once impactful were now mere shadows of their former selves, and the introduction of convoluted new mechanics only added to the confusion. The game lost its identity, leaving players yearning for the days when it was simpler and more engaging.

The single-player campaign, which had been touted as a major selling point, turned out to be a lackluster experience. The story was disjointed and riddled with plot holes, leaving players struggling to connect with the characters and their motivations. The missions lacked variety, often feeling repetitive and uninspired. The once-rich lore of Overwatch was squandered, leaving fans who had invested in the universe feeling betrayed.

As weeks turned into months, the community's frustration grew louder. Social media platforms were flooded with posts detailing the myriad issues with Overwatch 2, and players began to voice their concerns with the hashtag #FixOverwatch2. The developers attempted to address some of the problems through patches, but the changes often created new problems or were simply inadequate to address the underlying issues.

Ultimately, Overwatch 2 became a cautionary tale of the perils of rushed development and neglecting player feedback. The game that was meant to build upon the success of its predecessor ended up tarnishing the franchise's reputation. Long-time fans mourned the loss of what had once been a beloved game, and the gaming community as a whole couldn't help but feel disappointed by what had transpired.

Overwatch 2 stands as a reminder that even the most promising of sequels can falter when the developers lose sight of the elements that made the original great. It's a story of missed opportunities, broken promises, and a community left to grapple with the aftermath of a disappointing release.

Been playing since the alpha for the original Overwatch back in 2015, still enjoy it myself and play more or less daily. I don't care much for coop PVE games so I haven't tried that mode out, but they did release story missions if that's your jam. The story missions cost a one-time $15 fee to permanently unlock them.

There's a decent bit of cosmetic skins / microtransactions you can purchase, but they're all optional. Likewise, the $10 battlepasses unlock whatever new hero is released immediately if you don't want to play for 10 hours to unlock them from just naturally playing. Again, it's mostly just a speed boost thing, it's a free to play (now) after all.

If you're looking to just shooty mans in 5v5 matches, I'd definitely recommend it! Likewise, there's tons of custom gamemodes that folks make and release using the ingame custom game browser. There's even prophunt!!!!

Feel free to party up with me! :3

As a long time Overwatch player (Over 4 years and almost 1000 hours), I can confidently say that Overwatch is the king of Hero Shooters. 

You could definitely make an argument for Siege, but compared to Valorant, Overwatch offers highly dynamic gameplay, tons of fun, and a competitive scene if you're looking for a new esport title.

Seasonal releases have been up and down, but the game has continuously gotten better (except for S5 because they held content for Invasion). Launch was horrible compared to how the game was in Seasons 3, 4, and maybe 5. Season 6 (Invasion) is probably my favorite season yet!

The Devs are passionate and love the game, even if they're a bit... well... small indie company. They want to keep this game around for decades, so it seems that support won't be pulled anytime soon, and the Microsoft deal should help them get away from Bobby Kotick's (Activision Blizzard CEO's) tight control, which has sabotaged their game for as long as it's been around, and probably got the Hero Missions cancelled.

Overwatch offers a large roster of characters to choose, so you can definitely find your playstyle. A game definitely better with friends, does lack in-game tools to do so, but does offer crossplay and cross-progression. Compared to Tactical Shooters, Overwatch is faster-paced, and is more revolved around working as a team, however good players can carry a game... most of the time.

Overwatch 2 offers many different playstyles, even for those without an FPS Background. Tank and Support do not require the same level of aim, but offer very complicated mechanics for players to master, and different jobs to do in-game. Some heroes are easier than others, or are familiar to existing Shooter fans.

I personally prefer Overwatch and find Valorant a slog fest of checking the same angles and fighting in the same areas every time on each map. Overwatch 2 offers the freedom to move wherever on the map, without the threat of getting one tapped when you peek too wide. Though, you will get caught out if you are alone, or easy to kill. You want to stick near your team, but flanks are way more effective when most heroes can't one-shot you.

The game has an in-depth scripting engine (The Workshop), but no map editor. There are tons of custom gamemodes and seasonal limited-time modes put in the Arcade if you get tired of the normal unranked or ranked experience.

The PVE is fantastic, and I really enjoyed playing through King's Row: Underworld. I'm currently waiting for the Invasion Bundle to show up (There's a bug atm on Steam). We'll see about replayability. 

Overwatch is a PVP game first though, so don't expect any lavish RPG elements, because they got scrapped :/
Don't get discouraged by that though, there's so much fun to find.

The community is like other esports titles. It can be very toxic, OW fans are very passionate about the game and make their voices known. You just have to find like-minded people and you'll enjoy it a lot more. Competitive players are very loud, but if you want to compete, by all means do! If you're young, you can get a scholarship to college for playing this game!

Overall, if you're disappointed with the current main offerings of shooters (Valorant, COD, Apex, etc...) and are looking for something different, give Overwatch a shot! I know this game gets a bad rep, but give it a try, at least a few hours.

It's free after all!
